Award.AwardTitle: Function theory in CR geometry and partial differential equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Function theory in complex analysis has important applications to other branches of mathematics including algebraic geometry, applied mathematics, as well as to other disciplines, such as physics and engineering. For instance, in problems arising from electric fields, various geometric conditions can always be expressed in terms of functions of complex variables. By employing appropriate conformal maps, many inconvenient geometric configurations can be transformed to rather easy formats and hence be completely solved. Some other types of real-world phenomena are modeled as solutions to certain partial differential equations. Methods developed in complex analysis, such as Fourier analysis, have played fundamental roles in solving those equations and giving interpretations for solutions. The current project will address related problems in holomorphic function theory. Progress of the project will help us understand more precisely properties of conformal maps in higher dimensions and explore new methods that can be applied into other fields.

The PI proposes to study a variety of problems in several complex variables and the corresponding partial differential equations, together with her collaborators. More specifically, the PI will investigate rigidity and classification problems of CR embeddings between some special types of CR manifolds, such as (generalized) Heisenberg hypersurfaces. Since transversality property of CR mappings is closely related to CR embeddability, she also plans to continue the work on CR transversality along the line of the conjecture of Baouendi-Huang for Levi non-degenerate hypersurfaces of higher codimension. On the aspect of partial differential equations, the PI will work on regularity of solutions to Cauchy-Riemann equations over pseudoconvex domains through the method of integral representation theory. The method will involve strong correlation between holomorphic function theory and the geometry of the domains. The PI is also interested in the regularity problem for solutions to some Beltrami equations, as well as solvability and regularity to some general types of nonlinear elliptic complex partial differential equations on Heisenberg hypersurfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the funded period, the PI worked on function theory in several complex variables (SCV) and the related partial differential equations (PDEs). Specifically, the project investigated the embedding problems in CR geometry, solvability and regularity problems to the Cauchy-Riemann equations on pseudoconvex domains, and singular integral theory in complex analysis. Not only these problems span topics among harmonic analysis, PDEs, SCV and complex geometry, but the techniques that were developed in each of these problems have incorporated tools in the other areas naturally. One of the results used the Green function theory in PDEs to construct uniformly bounded canonical solutions to the Cauchy-Riemann equation in SCV. In particular, it answered an open problem of Kerzman in the continuity category.

During the grant period, there are seven papers published and/or accepted by peer-reviewed journals and four other preprints submitted for publication. The results of the work deepen the understanding of the complex and CR structure, and reveal the new connections between the function theory in several complex variables and the geometry of the ambient domains.

As an important branch of mathematics, complex analysis itself has already found numerous applications to other disciplines such as physical and engineering sciences, in the aspects such as signal processing, circuit analysis, and electrodynamics. The progress and methods in the outcome of the project should also have direct or indirect applications to those topics.

The PI disseminated the obtained research results in the project through presentations at conferences, workshops and seminars. In particular, the PI attended a series of activities held by American Women in Mathematics, such as a workshop at AIM institute, and an AMS special session, where the underrepresented groups were invited and actively involved.  Besides, parts of the outcomes are appropriate for the level of the graduate students.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/15/2020
Modified by: Yuan Zhang
